comments.text:
This isn't a subject I've done much research on, so I'm not familiar with 
studies on these creature's neurological workings, and how they experience 
different light rays etc.  But my initial instinct is to wonder if we're 
not over-complicating this here by forgetting our own experience of the 
world.

If I was walking around in an environment of a certain type (from a human 
perspective a pitch black forest) and I suddenly saw a light, I would be 
curious as to what it was because it would stand out.  If I thought it was 
dangerous, I might stay away.  If not, I'd go to investigate.  If I then 
found a whole group of non-threatening people at the light as well, I'd 
have reason to stay and come back again if I saw the same occurrence the 
next night, or somewhere else.  

So my first question is what are the studies on how these insects interact 
with each other.  Are they drawn to each other socially in other 
environments, or is it in their nature to avoid large gatherings of their 
species and similar species? 

Also, how much do we know of their brain capacities?  I find the clinical 
nature of studies tends to inadvertently paint a picture of a biological 
machine since it is only discussing functional how and why.  So I think its 
easy to forget that other life forms probably have psychological 
experiences of the world too.  Is it possible for a moth to be curious? 
What kind of data is there on this?

comments.text:
To my knowledge, an example of Phototaxism is when leaves fold/unfold in 
sunlight. Throughout a day, sunflowers continue pointed towards the sun, 
thus positively phototaxic, also, most flowers opening in the sunlight are 
positively phototaxic.
If you live around redwoods in California, a plant called redwood sorrel 
lives there. These are used to living in the shade, but when they are 
exposed to sunlight their petals or leaves (not sure which) fold down, 
reducing the amount of surface area exposed to sunlight, to prevent over 
heating! Thus they are negatively phototaxic.

Phototropism occurs when a plant is reaching towards light. The cells 
elongate on the dark side of the stalk, elongating that part, causing the 
stalk to bend towards the light!
